| influenced = [[Tunisian Revolution]], [[2011 Egyptian revolution]], [[2011 Libyan civil war]], [[Arab Spring]]

}}
â
'''Tareq al-Tayyib Muhammad Bouazizi''' (March 29, 1984 â January 4, 2011; {{lang-ar|Ø·Ø§Ø±Ù Ø§ÙØ·ÙØ¨ ÙØ­ÙØ¯ Ø§ÙØ¨ÙØ¹Ø²ÙØ²Ù}}<!--Tunisian pronunciation in IPA is needed-->), more commonly known as '''Mohamed Bouazizi''', was a [[Tunisia]]n street vendor who [[self-immolation|set himself on fire]] on December 17, 2010, in protest of the confiscation of his wares and the harassment and humiliation that he reported was inflicted on him by a municipal official and her aides. His act became a catalyst for the [[Tunisian Revolution]], inciting demonstrations and riots throughout Tunisia in protest of social and political issues in the country. The public's anger and violence intensified following Bouazizi's death, leading then-President [[Zine El Abidine Ben Ali]] to step down on January 14, 2011, after 23 years in power.
+
'''Tareq al-Tayyib Muhammad Bouazizi''' (March 29, 1984 â January 4, 2011; {{lang-ar|Ø·Ø§Ø±Ù Ø§ÙØ·ÙØ¨ ÙØ­ÙØ¯ Ø§ÙØ¨ÙØ¹Ø²ÙØ²Ù}}<!--Tunisian pronunciation in IPA is needed-->), known simply as '''Mohamed Bouazizi''', was a [[Tunisia]]n street vendor who [[self-immolation|set himself on fire]] on December 17, 2010, in protest of the confiscation of his wares and the harassment and humiliation that he reported was inflicted on him by a municipal official and her aides. His act became a catalyst for the [[Tunisian Revolution]], inciting demonstrations and riots throughout Tunisia in protest of social and political issues in the country. The public's anger and violence intensified following Bouazizi's death, leading then-President [[Zine El Abidine Ben Ali]] to step down on January 14, 2011, after 23 years in power.
The success of the Tunisian protests sparked [[Arab Spring|protests in several other Arab countries]], including a similar [[2011 Egyptian revolution|revolution in Egypt]], protests against the [[Yemen]]i and [[Syria]]n regimes, and the ongoing [[2011 Libyan civil war|civil war in Libya]]. The protests included several men who emulated Bouazizi's act of self-immolation, in an attempt to bring an end to their own [[Autocracy|autocratic]] governments. Those men and Bouazizi were hailed by some Arab commentators as "heroic martyrs of a new Middle Eastern revolution."<ref name="nytimes2">{{cite news|url=http://www.nytimes.com/2011/01/23/weekinreview/23worth.html?src=twrhp|title=How a Single Match Can Ignite a Revolution|author=Worth, Robert F.|work=New York Times|date=2011-01-21|accessdate=2011-01-26}}</ref>
The success of the Tunisian protests sparked [[Arab Spring|protests in several other Arab countries]], including a similar [[2011 Egyptian revolution|revolution in Egypt]], protests against the [[Yemen]]i and [[Syria]]n regimes, and the ongoing [[2011 Libyan civil war|civil war in Libya]]. The protests included several men who emulated Bouazizi's act of self-immolation, in an attempt to bring an end to their own [[Autocracy|autocratic]] governments. Those men and Bouazizi were hailed by some Arab commentators as "heroic martyrs of a new Middle Eastern revolution."<ref name="nytimes2">{{cite news|url=http://www.nytimes.com/2011/01/23/weekinreview/23worth.html?src=twrhp|title=How a Single Match Can Ignite a Revolution|author=Worth, Robert F.|work=New York Times|date=2011-01-21|accessdate=2011-01-26}}</ref>
Line 29: Line 29:
According to friends and family, local police officers had allegedly targeted and mistreated Bouazizi for years, including during his childhood, regularly confiscating his small wheelbarrow of produce;<ref name="aljazeera1"/> but Bouazizi no other way to make a living, so he continued to work as a street vendor. Around {{nowrap|10 p.m.}} on December 16, 2010, he had contracted approximately {{Currency|200}} in debt to buy the produce he was to sell the following day. On the morning of December 17, he started his workday at 8 am<ref name="guardian1"/> Just after {{nowrap|10:30 am}}, the police began harassing him again, ostensibly because he did not have a vendor's permit.<ref name="time mag">{{Citation|author=Abouzeid, Rania|title=Postcard: Sidi Bouzid|newspaper=[[Time (magazine)|TIME]]|page=8|date=2011-02-07}}</ref> However, while some sources state that [[street vending]] is illegal in Tunisia,<ref name="guardian2">{{cite news|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/commentisfree/2011/jan/19/tunisia-democratic-unity-government|author=Kherigi, Intissar|title=Tunisia needs real freedom|work=The Guardian |location=UK |date=2011-01-19|accessdate=2011-01-26}}</ref> and others that Bouazizi lacked a required permit to sell his wares,<ref name="guardian1"/><ref name="time mag"/> according to the head of Sidi Bouzid's state office for employment and independent work, no permit is needed to sell from a cart.<ref name="thenational1"/>
According to friends and family, local police officers had allegedly targeted and mistreated Bouazizi for years, including during his childhood, regularly confiscating his small wheelbarrow of produce;<ref name="aljazeera1"/> but Bouazizi no other way to make a living, so he continued to work as a street vendor. Around {{nowrap|10 p.m.}} on December 16, 2010, he had contracted approximately {{Currency|200}} in debt to buy the produce he was to sell the following day. On the morning of December 17, he started his workday at 8 am<ref name="guardian1"/> Just after {{nowrap|10:30 am}}, the police began harassing him again, ostensibly because he did not have a vendor's permit.<ref name="time mag">{{Citation|author=Abouzeid, Rania|title=Postcard: Sidi Bouzid|newspaper=[[Time (magazine)|TIME]]|page=8|date=2011-02-07}}</ref> However, while some sources state that [[street vending]] is illegal in Tunisia,<ref name="guardian2">{{cite news|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/commentisfree/2011/jan/19/tunisia-democratic-unity-government|author=Kherigi, Intissar|title=Tunisia needs real freedom|work=The Guardian |location=UK |date=2011-01-19|accessdate=2011-01-26}}</ref> and others that Bouazizi lacked a required permit to sell his wares,<ref name="guardian1"/><ref name="time mag"/> according to the head of Sidi Bouzid's state office for employment and independent work, no permit is needed to sell from a cart.<ref name="thenational1"/>
â
It has also been claimed that Bouazizi did not have the funds to bribe police officials to allow his street vending to continue.<ref name="guardian1"/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.csmonitor.com/World/Backchannels/2011/0114/Sticking-a-fork-in-Tunisia-s-Ben-Ali|author=Murphy, Dan|title=Sticking a fork in Tunisia's Ben Ali |publisher=[[Christian Science Monitor]] |date=2011-01-14|accessdate=2011-01-23}}</ref> Similarly, two of Bouazizi's siblings accused authorities of attempting to [[extort]] money from their brother,<ref name="thenational1"/> and during an interview with [[Reuters]], one of his sisters stated, "What kind of repression do you imagine it takes for a young man to do this? A man who has to feed his family by buying goods on credit when they fine him ... and take his goods. In Sidi Bouzid, those with no connections and no money for bribes are humiliated and insulted and not allowed to live."<ref name="reuters1"/>
+
Bouazizi did not have the funds to bribe police officials to allow his street vending to continue.<ref name="guardian1"/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.csmonitor.com/World/Backchannels/2011/0114/Sticking-a-fork-in-Tunisia-s-Ben-Ali|author=Murphy, Dan|title=Sticking a fork in Tunisia's Ben Ali |publisher=[[Christian Science Monitor]] |date=2011-01-14|accessdate=2011-01-23}}</ref> Similarly, two of Bouazizi's siblings accused authorities of attempting to [[extort]] money from their brother,<ref name="thenational1"/> and during an interview with [[Reuters]], one of his sisters stated, "What kind of repression do you imagine it takes for a young man to do this? A man who has to feed his family by buying goods on credit when they fine him ... and take his goods. In Sidi Bouzid, those with no connections and no money for bribes are humiliated and insulted and not allowed to live."<ref name="reuters1"/>
Regardless, Bouazizi's family claims he was publicly humiliated when a 45-year-old female [[municipal]] official, Faida Hamdi,<ref name="nytimes1"/><ref name="independent1">{{cite news|url=http://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/africa/tunisia-i-have-lost-my-son-but-i-am-proud-of-what-he-did-2190331.html|title=Tunisia: 'I have lost my son, but I am proud of what he did'|work=The Independent |location=UK |date=2011-01-21|accessdate=2011-01-23}}</ref><ref name="aljazeera1"/> slapped him in the face, spat at him, confiscated his electronic weighing [[scales]], and tossed aside his produce cart.<ref name="time mag"/> It was also stated that she made a slur against his deceased father.<ref name="reuters1"/><ref name="time mag"/> Bouazizi's family says her gender made his humiliation worse.<ref name="independent1"/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.habibtoumi.com/2010/12/31/man-at-the-centre-of-tunisia-unrest-recuperating-doctors-say|author=Toumi, Habib|title=Man at the centre of Tunisia unrest recuperating, doctors say|publisher=HabibToumi.com|date=2010-12-31|accessdate=2011-01-23}}</ref> His mother also claimed Hamdi's aides beat and swore at her son. Countering these claims, in an interview with ''[[Asharq Al-Awsat]]'', a brother of Hamdi claimed neither his sister nor her aides slapped or otherwise mistreated Bouazizi. He said they only confiscated Bouazizi's wares. However, an eyewitness told ''Asharq Al-Awsat'' that he did not see Hamdi slap Bouazizi, but that her aides did beat him.<ref name="AAA"/>
Regardless, Bouazizi's family claims he was publicly humiliated when a 45-year-old female [[municipal]] official, Faida Hamdi,<ref name="nytimes1"/><ref name="independent1">{{cite news|url=http://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/africa/tunisia-i-have-lost-my-son-but-i-am-proud-of-what-he-did-2190331.html|title=Tunisia: 'I have lost my son, but I am proud of what he did'|work=The Independent |location=UK |date=2011-01-21|accessdate=2011-01-23}}</ref><ref name="aljazeera1"/> slapped him in the face, spat at him, confiscated his electronic weighing [[scales]], and tossed aside his produce cart.<ref name="time mag"/> It was also stated that she made a slur against his deceased father.<ref name="reuters1"/><ref name="time mag"/> Bouazizi's family says her gender made his humiliation worse.<ref name="independent1"/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.habibtoumi.com/2010/12/31/man-at-the-centre-of-tunisia-unrest-recuperating-doctors-say|author=Toumi, Habib|title=Man at the centre of Tunisia unrest recuperating, doctors say|publisher=HabibToumi.com|date=2010-12-31|accessdate=2011-01-23}}</ref> His mother also claimed Hamdi's aides beat and swore at her son. Countering these claims, in an interview with ''[[Asharq Al-Awsat]]'', a brother of Hamdi claimed neither his sister nor her aides slapped or otherwise mistreated Bouazizi. He said they only confiscated Bouazizi's wares. However, an eyewitness told ''Asharq Al-Awsat'' that he did not see Hamdi slap Bouazizi, but that her aides did beat him.<ref name="AAA"/>
Line 44: Line 44:
==Aftermath==
==Aftermath==
â
Many [[Arab people|Arabs]] in the Middle East and North Africa see Bouazizi as a hero and inspiration.<ref name="ArabNews">{{cite web|url=http://arabnews.com/lifestyle/offbeat/article247965.ece|last=Jansen|first=Michael|title=Ben Ammar to produce film on Tunisian hero Bouazizi|publisher=[[Al-Sharq al-Awsat]]|work=[[Arab News]]|date=2011-02-01|accessdate=2011-04-11}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/world/2011/0118/1224287759638.html|last=Jansen|first=Michael|title=Egyptian injured in self-immolation protest|work=The Irish Times |work=The Irish Times |date=2011-01-18|accessdate=2011-04-11}}</ref> He is credited with galvanising the frustrations of the region's youth against their governments into mass demonstrations, revolts, and revolutions.<ref name="CNN">{{cite news|url=http://articles.cnn.com/2011-03-22/world/tunisia.bouazizi.arab.unrest_1_fruit-vendor-sidi-bouzid-abedine-ben-ali?_s=PM:WORLD|last=Watson|first=Ivan|title=The Tunisian fruit seller who kickstarted Arab uprising|publisher=Cable News Network|publisher=CNN|date=2011-03-22|accessdate=2011-04-11}}</ref> Bouazizi is considered a martyr by the [[Progressive Democratic Party (Tunisia)|Progressive Democratic Party]] (PDP) of Tunisia.<ref name="aljazeera1"/> Tunisian film director, [[Mohamed Zran]], plans on making a feature film about Bouazizi, describing him as "a symbol for eternity."<ref name="CNN"/> [[Tarak Ben Ammar]], also a Tunisian film director, intends to make a film on Bouazizi as well, stating he is "a hero for us as Tunisians and the Arab world as a whole."<ref name="ArabNews"/> Since suicide is forbidden in Islam, Bouazizi's self-immolation created controversy among scholarly Muslim circles. While [[al-Azhar]], the most prestigious religious institution in the [[Sunni Muslim]] world, issued a ''[[fatwa]]'' ("directive") stating "suicide violates Islam even when it is carried out as a social or political protest," influential Egyptian cleric [[Yusuf al-Qaradawi]] spoke sympathetically of Bouazizi.<ref name="nytimes2"/>
+
Many [[Arab people|Arabs]] in the Middle East and North Africa see Bouazizi as a hero and inspiration.<ref name="ArabNews">{{cite web|url=http://arabnews.com/lifestyle/offbeat/article247965.ece|last=Jansen|first=Michael|title=Ben Ammar to produce film on Tunisian hero Bouazizi|publisher=[[Al-Sharq al-Awsat]]|work=[[Arab News]]|date=2011-02-01|accessdate=2011-04-11}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/world/2011/0118/1224287759638.html|last=Jansen|first=Michael|title=Egyptian injured in self-immolation protest|work=The Irish Times |work=The Irish Times |date=2011-01-18|accessdate=2011-04-11}}</ref> He is credited with galvanising the frustrations of [[Arab Spring|the region's youth against their governments into mass demonstrations, revolts, and revolutions]].<ref name="CNN">{{cite news|url=http://articles.cnn.com/2011-03-22/world/tunisia.bouazizi.arab.unrest_1_fruit-vendor-sidi-bouzid-abedine-ben-ali?_s=PM:WORLD|last=Watson|first=Ivan|title=The Tunisian fruit seller who kickstarted Arab uprising|publisher=Cable News Network|publisher=CNN|date=2011-03-22|accessdate=2011-04-11}}</ref> Bouazizi is considered a martyr by the [[Progressive Democratic Party (Tunisia)|Progressive Democratic Party]] (PDP) of Tunisia.<ref name="aljazeera1"/> Tunisian film director, [[Mohamed Zran]], plans on making a feature film about Bouazizi, describing him as "a symbol for eternity."<ref name="CNN"/> [[Tarak Ben Ammar]], also a Tunisian film director, intends to make a film on Bouazizi as well, stating he is "a hero for us as Tunisians and the Arab world as a whole."<ref name="ArabNews"/> Since suicide is forbidden in Islam, Bouazizi's self-immolation created controversy among scholarly Muslim circles. While [[al-Azhar]], the most prestigious religious institution in the [[Sunni Muslim]] world, issued a ''[[fatwa]]'' ("directive") stating "suicide violates Islam even when it is carried out as a social or political protest," influential Egyptian cleric [[Yusuf al-Qaradawi]] spoke sympathetically of Bouazizi.<ref name="nytimes2"/>
On February 17, 2011, the main square in Tunis that was previously called "November 7", after the date of Ben Ali's take-over in 1987, was renamed after Bouazizi.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://af.reuters.com/article/topNews/idAFJOE71G0MB20110217|title=Tunis renames square after man who sparked protests|agency=Reuters |date=2011-02-17}}</ref> Prior to that, on February 4, [[Bertrand DelanoÃ«]], the mayor of Paris, announced that, as a tribute to honour Bouazizi, a square in Paris will be named after him.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5ij_goZCOky4OIGq3YqNg-qGjovwQ?docId=CNG.0fc7842c814225c17320c2d9273bc7b9.641|author=[[Agence France-Presse]]|title=DelanoÃ« veut donner le nom du jeune Tunisien immolÃ© Ã  un lieu parisien ''(French)''|publisher=[[Google News]]|date=2011-02-04|accessdate=2011-02-05}}</ref>
On February 17, 2011, the main square in Tunis that was previously called "November 7", after the date of Ben Ali's take-over in 1987, was renamed after Bouazizi.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://af.reuters.com/article/topNews/idAFJOE71G0MB20110217|title=Tunis renames square after man who sparked protests|agency=Reuters |date=2011-02-17}}</ref> Prior to that, on February 4, [[Bertrand DelanoÃ«]], the mayor of Paris, announced that, as a tribute to honour Bouazizi, a square in Paris will be named after him.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5ij_goZCOky4OIGq3YqNg-qGjovwQ?docId=CNG.0fc7842c814225c17320c2d9273bc7b9.641|author=[[Agence France-Presse]]|title=DelanoÃ« veut donner le nom du jeune Tunisien immolÃ© Ã  un lieu parisien ''(French)''|publisher=[[Google News]]|date=2011-02-04|accessdate=2011-02-05}}</ref>
